channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Proteome census upon nutrient stress reveals Golgiphagy membrane receptors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06657-6

Proteome census upon nutrient stress reveals Golgiphagy membrane receptors
item.dc:title: Proteome census upon nutrient stress reveals Golgiphagy membrane receptors
item.dc:creator: Kelsey L. Hickey
Sharan Swarup
Ian R. Smith
Julia C. Paoli
Enya Miguel Whelan
Joao A. Paulo
J. Wade Harper

item.title: RSV treatments are here: now the work begins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02955-1

Efforts to prevent infections and keep vulnerable people out of hospital are beginning to pay off, but deploying these strategies presents new challenges.
item.dc:title: RSV treatments are here: now the work begins
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Plackett

item.title: The very first beat: how a heart starts to pulse
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03052-z

Hours of footage of zebrafish embryos let researchers capture and study this key moment in development.
item.dc:title: The very first beat: how a heart starts to pulse
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: Scientists achieve the tricky task of compressing liquids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03032-3

Using a metal organic framework, researchers reduced the volume of a water-based mixture by 7%.
item.dc:title: Scientists achieve the tricky task of compressing liquids
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Observation of the effect of gravity on the motion of antimatter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06527-1

Magnetically confined neutral antihydrogen atoms released in a gravity field were found to fall towards Earth like ordinary matter, in accordance with Einstein’s general theory of relativity.
item.dc:title: Observation of the effect of gravity on the motion of antimatter

item.title: Protected areas slow declines unevenly across the tetrapod tree of life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06562-y

An analysis of 2,239 terrestrial vertebrate populations shows that they decline more slowly in protected areas than outside protected areas, but the benefits vary across vertebrate classes and depend on the regional context of the protected area.
item.dc:title: Protected areas slow declines unevenly across the tetrapod tree of life
item.dc:creator: A. Justin Nowakowski
James I. Watling
Alexander Murray
Jessica L. Deichmann
Thomas S. Akre
Carlos L. Muñoz Brenes
Brian D. Todd
Louise McRae
Robin Freeman
Luke O. Frishkoff

item.title: Uniquely preserved gut contents illuminate trilobite palaeophysiology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06567-7

Fossilized gut contents of an Ordovician trilobite shed light on the feeding habits of one of the most common and well-known extinct arthropods.
item.dc:title: Uniquely preserved gut contents illuminate trilobite palaeophysiology
item.dc:creator: Petr Kraft
Valéria Vaškaninová
Michal Mergl
Petr Budil
Oldřich Fatka
Per E. Ahlberg

item.title: Weather explains the decline and rise of insect biomass over 34 years
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06402-z

Insect biomass data covering 27 years were reanalysed using sample-specific information on weather conditions during sampling and weather anomalies during the insect life cycle, finding that biomass is driven by complex weather conditions.
item.dc:title: Weather explains the decline and rise of insect biomass over 34 years
item.dc:creator: Jörg Müller
Torsten Hothorn
Ye Yuan
Sebastian Seibold
Oliver Mitesser
Julia Rothacher
Julia Freund
Clara Wild
Marina Wolz
Annette Menzel

item.title: Seasonal advance of intense tropical cyclones in a warming climate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06544-0

We identify a seasonal advance of intense tropical cyclones that is closely related to the seasonal advance of rapid intensification events, favoured by the observed earlier onset of favourable oceanic conditions.
item.dc:title: Seasonal advance of intense tropical cyclones in a warming climate
item.dc:creator: Kaiyue Shan
Yanluan Lin
Pao-Shin Chu
Xiping Yu
Fengfei Song

item.title: The geography of climate and the global patterns of species diversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06577-5

Nearly 90% of global variation in species richness of birds, mammals, amphibians and reptiles is shown to be explained by the joint effects of climate and the geographic structure (area and isolation) of climate.
item.dc:title: The geography of climate and the global patterns of species diversity
item.dc:creator: Marco Túlio P. Coelho
Elisa Barreto
Thiago F. Rangel
José Alexandre F. Diniz-Filho
Rafael O. Wüest
Wilhelmine Bach
Alexander Skeels
Ian R. McFadden
David W. Roberts
Loïc Pellissier
Niklaus E. Zimmermann
Catherine H. Graham

item.title: A quantum engine in the BEC–BCS crossover
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06469-8

This study reports the creation of a model thermodynamic engine that is fuelled by the energy difference resulting from changing the statistics of a quantum gas from bosonic to fermionic.
item.dc:title: A quantum engine in the BEC–BCS crossover
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Koch
Keerthy Menon
Eloisa Cuestas
Sian Barbosa
Eric Lutz
Thomás Fogarty
Thomas Busch
Artur Widera

item.title: Electrically driven organic laser using integrated OLED pumping
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06488-5

An electrically driven organic semiconductor laser is achieved by integrating a device structure that efficiently couples an organic light-emitting diode, with extremely high internal-light generation, with a polymer distributed feedback laser.
item.dc:title: Electrically driven organic laser using integrated OLED pumping
item.dc:creator: Kou Yoshida
Junyi Gong
Alexander L. Kanibolotsky
Peter J. Skabara
Graham A. Turnbull
Ifor D. W. Samuel

item.title: Inactivation of the Kv2.1 channel through electromechanical coupling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06582-8

The exploration of voltage-gated potassium channels using cryo-electron microscopy and electrophysiology identifies a mechanism of inactivation involved in regulating neuron firing.
item.dc:title: Inactivation of the Kv2.1 channel through electromechanical coupling
item.dc:creator: Ana I. Fernández-Mariño
Xiao-Feng Tan
Chanhyung Bae
Kate Huffer
Jiansen Jiang
Kenton J. Swartz

item.title: Precessing jet nozzle connecting to a spinning black hole in M87
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06479-6

This study analyses radio observations of the jet in galaxy M87, from which the existence of a spinning black hole that induces Lense–Thirring precession of a misaligned accretion disk is inferred.
item.dc:title: Precessing jet nozzle connecting to a spinning black hole in M87
item.dc:creator: Yuzhu Cui

item.title: Transposon-encoded nucleases use guide RNAs to promote their selfish spread
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06597-1

TnpB and IscB nucleases use transposon-encoded guide RNAs to target genomic sequences for cleavage, thereby favouring copying and spreading of transposable elements.
item.dc:title: Transposon-encoded nucleases use guide RNAs to promote their selfish spread
item.dc:creator: Chance Meers
Hoang C. Le
Sanjana R. Pesari
Florian T. Hoffmann
Matt W. G. Walker
Jeanine Gezelle
Stephen Tang
Samuel H. Sternberg

item.title: A bioelectrical phase transition patterns the first vertebrate heartbeats
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06561-z

The first heartbeat of a zebrafish was captured, and development of cardiac excitability and conduction around this singular event were analysed, showing how development of single-cell properties produces a transition from quiescence to coordinated beating.
item.dc:title: A bioelectrical phase transition patterns the first vertebrate heartbeats
item.dc:creator: Bill Z. Jia
Yitong Qi
J. David Wong-Campos
Sean G. Megason
Adam E. Cohen

item.title: Earth’s early continental crust formed from wet and oxidizing arc magmas
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06552-0

The use of two zircon oxybarometers to simultaneously determine fO2 and H2O contents shows that Archaean granitoids were mostly formed from relatively oxidizing and H2O-rich magmas, probably at ancient subduction zones.
item.dc:title: Earth’s early continental crust formed from wet and oxidizing arc magmas
item.dc:creator: Rong-Feng Ge
Simon A. Wilde
Wen-Bin Zhu
Xiao-Lei Wang

item.title: Dopaminergic error signals retune to social feedback during courtship
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06580-w

In male zebra finches, dopamine responses in Area X are retuned away from self-evaluation of song performance and towards social feedback to song performance when females are present.
item.dc:title: Dopaminergic error signals retune to social feedback during courtship
item.dc:creator: Andrea Roeser
Vikram Gadagkar
Anindita Das
Pavel A. Puzerey
Brian Kardon
Jesse H. Goldberg

item.title: Inhibition of fatty acid oxidation enables heart regeneration in adult mice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06585-5

Inhibition of the fatty acid oxidation metabolic pathway through inactivation of Cpt1b enhances cardiomyocyte survival and proliferation and allows heart regeneration in adult mice.
item.dc:title: Inhibition of fatty acid oxidation enables heart regeneration in adult mice
item.dc:creator: Xiang Li
Fan Wu
Stefan Günther
Mario Looso
Carsten Kuenne
Ting Zhang
Marion Wiesnet

Thomas Braun

item.title: Molecular pathology of neurodegenerative diseases by cryo-EM of amyloids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06437-2

Structural studies of amyloid filaments purified from brains of people with neurodegenerative diseases link specific amyloid folds with distinct diseases and provide a basis for the development of models of neurodegenerative disease.
item.dc:title: Molecular pathology of neurodegenerative diseases by cryo-EM of amyloids
item.dc:creator: Sjors H. W. Scheres
Benjamin Ryskeldi-Falcon
Michel Goedert

item.title: Assembloid CRISPR screens reveal impact of disease genes in human neurodevelopment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06564-w

Assembloids are integrated with CRISPR screening to investigate the involvement of 425 neurodevelopmental disorder genes in human interneuron development, showing endoplasmic reticulum displacement before nuclear translocation and interference from LNPK deletion, resulting in abnormal migration.
item.dc:title: Assembloid CRISPR screens reveal impact of disease genes in human neurodevelopment
item.dc:creator: Xiangling Meng
David Yao
Kent Imaizumi
Xiaoyu Chen
Kevin W. Kelley
Noah Reis
Mayuri Vijay Thete
Arpana Arjun McKinney
Shravanti Kulkarni
Georgia Panagiotakos
Michael C. Bassik
Sergiu P. Pașca

item.title: Spatial atlas of the mouse central nervous system at molecular resolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06569-5

In situ spatial transcriptomic analysis of more than 1 million cells are used to create a 200-nm-resolution spatial molecular atlas of the adult mouse central nervous system and identify previously unknown tissue architectures.
item.dc:title: Spatial atlas of the mouse central nervous system at molecular resolution
item.dc:creator: Hailing Shi
Yichun He
Yiming Zhou

item.title: piRNA processing by a trimeric Schlafen-domain nuclease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06588-2

The endoribonuclease PUCH, a trimer of Schlafen-like-domain proteins, initiates piRNA processing in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans through 5′-end piRNA precursor cleavage.
item.dc:title: piRNA processing by a trimeric Schlafen-domain nuclease
item.dc:creator: Nadezda Podvalnaya
Alfred W. Bronkhorst
Raffael Lichtenberger

René F. Ketting

item.title: Resonant X-ray excitation of the nuclear clock isomer <sup>45</sup>Sc
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06491-w

Resonant X-ray excitation of the 45Sc nuclear isomeric state was achieved by irradiation of a Sc-metal foil with 12.4-keV photon pulses from a state-of-the-art X-ray free-electron laser, allowing a high-precision determination of the transition energy.
item.dc:title: Resonant X-ray excitation of the nuclear clock isomer <sup>45</sup>Sc
item.dc:creator: Yuri Shvyd’ko

item.title: An all-organic laser that is electrically driven
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02935-5

An organic light-emitting diode has been integrated with an optically driven organic laser to produce laser light from electricity. The design bypasses many of the challenges posed by direct electrical input in such devices.
item.dc:title: An all-organic laser that is electrically driven
item.dc:creator: Stéphane Kéna-Cohen

item.title: Measuring the ecological benefits of protected areas
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02676-5

Are protected areas slowing down global biodiversity declines? A global analysis provides evidence that they are, although effects vary across groups of species, and what happens outside protected areas matters, too.
item.dc:title: Measuring the ecological benefits of protected areas
item.dc:creator: Ana S. L. Rodrigues
Marie-Morgane Rouyer

item.title: Respiratory syncytial virus co-infections might conspire to worsen disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02959-x

Emerging evidence suggests that pathogens can pair up to work together against immune system defences.
item.dc:title: Respiratory syncytial virus co-infections might conspire to worsen disease
item.dc:creator: Katherine Bourzac

item.title: Universities axe diversity statements in wake of US Supreme Court ruling on affirmative action
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03049-8

Higher-education campaigners fear that removing the option for job applicants to provide the statements will make the academic workforce less diverse.
item.dc:title: Universities axe diversity statements in wake of US Supreme Court ruling on affirmative action
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt

item.title: The search for a connection between RSV and asthma
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02961-3

The consequences of respiratory syncytial virus infection sometimes linger for years — and scientists are trying to work out whether there’s a causal link.
item.dc:title: The search for a connection between RSV and asthma
item.dc:creator: Sandy Ong

item.title: AI and science: what 1,600 researchers think
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02980-0

A Nature survey finds that scientists are concerned, as well as excited, by the increasing use of artificial-intelligence tools in research.
item.dc:title: AI and science: what 1,600 researchers think
item.dc:creator: Richard Van Noorden
Jeffrey M. Perkel

item.title: COVID lockdowns altered babies’ microbiomes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02994-8

Isolation can have lasting effects on the composition of microbes in the gut, but links to other health conditions are still poorly understood.
item.dc:title: COVID lockdowns altered babies’ microbiomes
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer

item.title: Coordinating the first heartbeat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02938-2

An impressive combination of computational modelling and experimental techniques in live zebrafish embryos reveals how the heart initiates its organized and rhythmic beating.
item.dc:title: Coordinating the first heartbeat
item.dc:creator: Joshua Bloomekatz
Neil C. Chi

item.title: What’s the best chatbot for me? Researchers put LLMs through their paces
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03023-4

When it comes to large language models, there’s one for every occasion. Find the most appropriate match for you in our AI speed-dating feature.
item.dc:title: What’s the best chatbot for me? Researchers put LLMs through their paces
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth M. Humphries
Carrie Wright
Ava M. Hoffman
Candace Savonen
Jeffrey T. Leek

item.title: This isn’t the Nature Podcast — how deepfakes are distorting reality
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03042-1

The rise of AI-generated fakes, evidence of the earliest-known wooden structure, and how NASA’s OSIRIS-REx brought asteroid samples back to Earth.
item.dc:title: This isn’t the Nature Podcast — how deepfakes are distorting reality
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: A trilobite’s last meal reveals feeding behaviour and physiology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02773-5

The gut contents of a fossilized trilobite, Bohemolichas incola, from the Ordovician period (about 465 million years ago), were imaged by a technique called synchrotron microtomography and fully itemized. The results indicate that the animal fed indiscriminately on small shelly invertebrates and that its gut had a neutral to alkaline pH.
item.dc:title: A trilobite’s last meal reveals feeding behaviour and physiology

item.title: Antibody therapies set to transform respiratory syncytial virus prevention for babies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02957-z

Drugs that counter RSV infection can safeguard newborns, offering another mode of protection alongside vaccines.
item.dc:title: Antibody therapies set to transform respiratory syncytial virus prevention for babies
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Fear of the dark
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03002-9

The invisible enemy.
item.dc:title: Fear of the dark
item.dc:creator: Stephen Battersby

item.title: AI will transform science — now researchers must tame it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02988-6

A new Nature series will explore the many ways in which artificial intelligence is changing science — for better and for worse.
item.dc:title: AI will transform science — now researchers must tame it

item.title: Science and the new age of AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03017-2

A Nature special on how AI is transforming the scientific enterprise.
item.dc:title: Science and the new age of AI

item.title: Research round-up: respiratory syncytial virus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02962-2

Why monitoring sewers could help to detect outbreaks, how RSV and flu viruses can couple together and other highlights.
item.dc:title: Research round-up: respiratory syncytial virus
item.dc:creator: Liam Drew

item.title: How to stop AI deepfakes from sinking society — and science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02990-y

Deceptive videos and images created using generative AI could sway elections, crash stock markets and ruin reputations. Researchers are developing methods to limit their harm.
item.dc:title: How to stop AI deepfakes from sinking society — and science
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: Boomerang academics: why we left academia for industry, but then came back
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03000-x

A move from one sector to another isn’t a one-way street. Researchers who have pivoted between the two explain why.
item.dc:title: Boomerang academics: why we left academia for industry, but then came back
item.dc:creator: Christine Ro

item.title: Antimatter falls down, not up: CERN experiment confirms theory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03043-0

Observing this simple phenomenon had eluded physicists for decades.
item.dc:title: Antimatter falls down, not up: CERN experiment confirms theory
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: This octopus-inspired patch could deliver drugs like Ozempic through your cheek
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03050-1

Small rubber suction cups filled with medication were better than tablets at delivering compounds into the bloodstream.
item.dc:title: This octopus-inspired patch could deliver drugs like Ozempic through your cheek
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Better awareness of RSV in older adults is needed to fight a growing burden
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02958-y

Respiratory syncytial virus is usually associated with babies, but the virus can also cause serious disease in older adults and people with chronic medical conditions.
item.dc:title: Better awareness of RSV in older adults is needed to fight a growing burden
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer

item.title: The twisted material that splits the electron
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02941-7

Layers of a thin semiconductor material overlap in a particular pattern, giving rise to particle currents carrying a fraction of the charge of an electron — with potential for encoding quantum information.
item.dc:title: The twisted material that splits the electron
item.dc:creator: Cécile Repellin

item.title: Flying Mars rocks to Earth could cost an astronomical $11 billion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03034-1

NASA’s Perseverance rover has collected valuable samples, but a new report says the plan to fetch them is unworkable.
item.dc:title: Flying Mars rocks to Earth could cost an astronomical $11 billion
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Tracking RSV in low- and middle-income countries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02960-4

By surveilling respiratory syncytial virus, the World Health Organization is hoping to understand who the virus infects and the burden it has.
item.dc:title: Tracking RSV in low- and middle-income countries
item.dc:creator: Pratik Pawar

item.title: The geography of climate governs biodiversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02937-3

To explain the interplay of climate, area and isolation that underlies the marked global differences in biodiversity, a switch in focus from geographic space to climatic space offers a way forwards.
item.dc:title: The geography of climate governs biodiversity
item.dc:creator: Antonin Machac

item.title: Vaccines could offer fresh hope against respiratory syncytial virus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02956-0

If deployed effectively and equitably, this latest generation of vaccines could help to prevent countless deaths and hospitalizations among the young and old.
item.dc:title: Vaccines could offer fresh hope against respiratory syncytial virus
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: For Indigenous infants, RSV prevention is better than a cure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02963-1

Governments need to put remote communities at the forefront of strategies to prevent the respiratory disease.
item.dc:title: For Indigenous infants, RSV prevention is better than a cure
item.dc:creator: Anna Banerji

item.title: Global warming is advancing the season for intense tropical cyclones
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02800-5

A data analysis shows that these destructive tropical storms are shifting earlier in the season all over the globe, owing mainly to anthropogenic climate warming. This seasonal advance could increase the likelihood of the storms overlapping with other extreme weather events, and has implications for disaster prevention.
item.dc:title: Global warming is advancing the season for intense tropical cyclones

item.title: Scandium-45 nuclear-clock candidate driven by X-ray lasers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02791-3

Precise timekeeping is key to many technologies, motivating the search for more-stable reference oscillators for use as clocks. The resonant X-ray excitation of a long-lived nuclear state in scandium-45 makes it a potential reference oscillator for a nuclear clock that could surpass atomic clocks in stability and resilience against external perturbations.
item.dc:title: Scandium-45 nuclear-clock candidate driven by X-ray lasers

item.title: AI tools as science policy advisers? The potential and the pitfalls
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02999-3

Large language models and other artificial-intelligence systems could be excellent at synthesizing scientific evidence for policymakers — but only with appropriate safeguards and humans in the loop.
item.dc:title: AI tools as science policy advisers? The potential and the pitfalls
item.dc:creator: Chris Tyler
K. L. Akerlof
Alessandro Allegra
Zachary Arnold
Henriette Canino
Marius A. Doornenbal
Josh A. Goldstein
David Budtz Pedersen
William J. Sutherland

item.title: Free-falling antihydrogen reveals the effect of gravity on antimatter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02930-w

A test performed on antihydrogen atoms has shown that gravity acts on matter and antimatter in a similar way. The experimental feat is the latest in efforts to probe the crossover between theories of relativity and particle physics.
item.dc:title: Free-falling antihydrogen reveals the effect of gravity on antimatter
item.dc:creator: Anna Soter

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03010-9

Insects that traipse across winter snowfields use harsh technique to keep their internal organs from freezing.
item.dc:title: Snow-loving flies amputate their own legs for survival

item.title: Replication games: how to make reproducibility research more systematic
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02997-5

In some areas of social science, around half of studies can’t be replicated. A new test-fast, fail-fast initiative aims to show what research is hot — and what’s not.
item.dc:title: Replication games: how to make reproducibility research more systematic
item.dc:creator: Abel Brodeur
Anna Dreber
Fernando Hoces de la Guardia
Edward Miguel

item.title: A new era for Arecibo: legendary observatory begins next phase
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03021-6

The US National Science Foundation announces plan to use the historic site for biology and computer science education.
item.dc:title: A new era for Arecibo: legendary observatory begins next phase
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza

item.title: Research at the intersection of ‘human rage and nature’s fury’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03031-4

Geochemist Charles Balagizi monitors water safety and volcanic activity in a region where violence is common. The deaths of colleagues means he never assumes an area is safe.
item.dc:title: Research at the intersection of ‘human rage and nature’s fury’
item.dc:creator: Shihab Jamal

item.title: Daily briefing: Earth’s next supercontinent will be a giant desert
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03041-2

Up to 92% of Earth could be uninhabitable to mammals in 250 million years. Plus, millions of people live on land contaminated by metal mining and how Dolly the sheep’s legacy lives on.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Earth’s next supercontinent will be a giant desert
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: How tackling real-world problems transformed my teaching and research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02989-5

Designing courses on the basis of what really matters to people is a win–win for students and society.
item.dc:title: How tackling real-world problems transformed my teaching and research
item.dc:creator: Franco Montalto

item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: ‘If I drop this, I’ll kill the queen’: how I launched a veterinary practice for bees
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03001-w

Elizabeth Hilborn is among just a handful of people in the United States who are medically trained to treat honey bees.
item.dc:title: ‘If I drop this, I’ll kill the queen’: how I launched a veterinary practice for bees
item.dc:creator: Fern Reiss

item.title: COVID vaccines linked to unexpected vaginal bleeding
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02996-6

A large cohort study measured how frequently women reported bleeding after receiving COVID-19 jabs.
item.dc:title: COVID vaccines linked to unexpected vaginal bleeding
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Shock delay to net-zero pledges turns UK from climate leader to laggard
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02987-7

It could have shown vision and leadership. Instead, the country that proudly hosted the 2021 COP26 climate summit is ignoring the advice of its own researchers.
item.dc:title: Shock delay to net-zero pledges turns UK from climate leader to laggard

item.title: How Dolly the sheep’s legacy lives on: CRISPR cattle and cloned camels
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02921-x

Dolly-style animal cloning underpins CRISPR livestock, but changes loom for the field.
item.dc:title: How Dolly the sheep’s legacy lives on: CRISPR cattle and cloned camels
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford
